Amul: This is located just inside the H12-13-14 complex. As IIT-B's only proper ice-cream parlour, this is a fine place to be for your late-night dessert cravings. They also serve sandwiches and other light snacks.
Brewberrys: Located right just inside Hostel-8, this cafe is commonly used for treats, dates and meetings. The cafe has good variety and serves some great coffee, pizzas and sandwiches. Priced slightly higher than canteens, this is a great place to be if you're in the mood for something reasonably priced, beyond your standard fare.
Campus Hub: Situated near Hostel-5, Campus Hub is famous for its juices, shakes and chaat. It also offers a decent offering of cakes, ice-creams, fruits and more traditional items. We recommend the price-conscious to avoid full meals, but the other items are well worth it.
Chikoo and sitaphal milkshakes (when available), sev-puri
Chem: This is located on the first floor of the Chemical Department building. Famed for serving some of the best samosas on campus, this hidden gem is worth the trip from your department.
Elec: Located at the third floor of the Girish Gaitonde building, this serves a fine breakfast/snack menu, with poha, samosa, idlis and tea besides packaged items. A good option for a filling morning meal.
Gullu: A stone's throw from KResIT, this is the one place where IIT Bombay students can have restaurant-grade food at decent rates. A standard location for treats and eating 'out' within campus, Gullu is a popular, often-crowded place offering great options for both Indian and especially non-Indian (Oriental) cuisines.
Gullu Café: A nifty little place near the academic area for a quick food break. Dosas, pav-bhaji, sandwiches, pakodas, and all the chaats you can imagine. Frequented by students and faculty alike.
H1 canteen: H1 has one of the more popular canteens, with a spacious seating area and cheap, tasty offerings.
H10 canteen: As the only hostel near the academic area, H10 sees it's canteen make good profits from hungry students coming out of their departments visit it for a late night meal. Given the campus' skewed sex ratio, it's not uncommon to see an equal number of men and women here
H11 canteen: H11 is one of those mystical areas that not much is known about. We hear rumours that the canteen's not bad.
H12 canteen: This underground hostel canteen sees students flocking from many hostels, since it is one of the last places to close at night. Apart from standard canteen fare, it also serves a host of desserts and baked goods.
H15 canteen: Located in the H15 mess, this is a prime spot for cash-strapped freshies to give treats that are thrust upon them. On further thought, *every* hostel canteen is the place for students to give treats that are thrust upon them.
H16 canteen: This one's a little new (barely a couple of years old), so the workflow isn't as smooth as other hostels, but the menu offers much of the same standardized items that you get in other canteens
Chola dry with Paranthas, Veg triple rice
H2 canteen: The H2 canteen is well-liked by its inmates and outsiders. The egg-and-maggi combinations are always worth a shot, as are the frankies.
Topi maggi (get the egg to be half-fried) with cheese
H3 canteen: The H3 canteen has seen many changes over the years, so rest assured you won't find the same experience if you're an alumnus. The new canteen is famous for its egg and rice dishes.
H4 canteen: H4's canteen opens out to a large(ish) garden, and is perfect for winter evenings. Beware of mosquitos though.
H5 canteen: The canteen’s location within the mess, which means that not only is the mosquito problem is less severe, but also, if you go at meal times, you can get food simultaneously from the mess and the canteen
H6 canteen: Given that the H6 canteen is attached to the lounge, it provides a nice space for you to have your meal. This canteen is also famous for its innovative dishes, which are hard to find elsewhere.
Fried Curry Maggi, Boiled Egg Bhurji
H7 canteen: It's a little short on chairs, and prone to mosquito swarms, but the menu is unique, and the food solid.
H8 canteen: Ever get hungry just walking from the academic area to the hostels? H8 is right on the way. Stop by for some of the best canteen cooking on the campus, and a view of the lake.
H9 canteen: If you're a dog-lover, this is the canteen to go to. A fridge that's always stocked full with drinks, and the availability of an optional cheese version of pretty much everything on the menu add to the charm.
Shakti (Ahar): The Ahar is run by Shakti (ladies club) and is located behind the building. It offers a variety of traditional Marathi foods, which are hard to find elsewhere.
KReSIT: Extremely crowded after classes, this is the ideal place to grab your cuppa with some tasty samosa after a hard day in the lecture halls. It's dirt-cheap rates and prime location near the academic area make it one of the more popular hangout spots on campus.
Tea (easily the best on campus), Samosa with coconut chutney
Main Gate: This is more of a general store than an eating joint, but hey, whatever floats your boat. In tea.
Shack: Situated right in the middle of the academic area, this is a great place for a refreshing cold coffee or iced tea when you're taking a ‘break' from lectures. The Shack is an institution by itself in IITB, and you can always find interesting company here.
StaffC: Positioned down a flight of stairs in near the Main Building security office, the staff canteen offers a decent spread of hot cooked snacks. This is the place to be for some cheap meals, if you happen to be in the Main building area.
Sunrise: The Dhaba is located right opposite the Students Activity Centre, and serves a menu designed to provide fast and hygienic food. Their thali is the ideal thing for lazy weekend afternoons.
Tansa Canteen: This is only place in the institute to serve fish. With eye-watering tadka constantly being prepared here, this is worth a visit for your pescatarian cravings.
YP: This is a long running institution requented by staff and other campus dwellers. It's close to the market, so you can end up here right after shopping for fruits, stationery, or the much needed haircut you've been avoiding.
Tapri: A minimal range of items: tea, cigarettes, and occasionally hot Bournvita. But hey, who else is going to be open at 4.30 in the morning? Needless to say, this is strictly a, ahem, take-way place.
H1 Mess: Hostel Messes serve four meals a day, and vary the menu constantly. The food is... allegedly edible.
H2 Mess: Hostel Messes serve four meals a day, and vary the menu constantly. The food is... allegedly edible.
